data.enText: a layer of bricks, concrete, etc. that forms the solid underground base of a building

data.chText: 建筑工人正开始给新校舍打地基。
data.enText: The builders are now beginning to lay the foundations of the new school.

data.chText: 爆炸震撼了附近房屋的地基。
data.enText: The explosion shook the foundations of the houses nearby.
a principle, an idea or a fact that sth is based on and that it grows from

data.chText: 尊重和友爱是婚姻的牢固基础。
data.enText: Respect and friendship provide a solid foundation for marriage.
The rumour is totally without foundation (= not based on any facts) .
These stories have no foundation (= are not based on any facts) .
an organization that is established to provide money for a particular purpose, for example for scientific research or charity

data.chText: 这笔钱将交给旧金山艾滋病基金会。
data.enText: The money will go to the San Francisco AIDS Foundation.
the act of starting a new institution or organization

data.chText: 该组织自1955年创建以来已有重大的发展。
data.enText: The organization has grown enormously since its foundation in 1955.
a skin-coloured cream that is put on the face underneath other make-up
shake/rock the foundations of sth
shake/rock sth to its foundations
to cause people to question their basic beliefs about sth

data.chText: 这个问题从根本上动摇了法国的政治。
data.enText: This issue has shaken the foundations of French politics.

data.chText: 以上各词均指基础、根据。
data.enText: These are all words for the ideas or facts that sth is based on.
basis
[usually sing.] a principle, an idea or a fact that supports sth and that it can develop from

data.chText: 这篇文章将作为我们讨论的基点。
data.enText: This article will form the basis for our discussion.
foundation
[usually sing.] a principle, an idea or a fact that supports sth and that it develops from

data.chText: 尊重和伴侣关系是婚姻的牢固基础。
data.enText: Respect and friendship provide a solid foundation for marriage.
The rumour is totally without foundation (= is not based on any facts) .

data.chText: 与basis相比，foundation常用以指更大、更重要的事物：
data.enText: Foundation is often used to talk about larger or more important things than basis .

data.chText: 他奠定了日本现代经济的基础。
data.enText: He laid the foundation of Japan's modern economy.

data.chText: 这些数字是他们要求提高工资的根据。
data.enText: These figures formed the basis of their pay claim.
basis or foundation?
base
[usually sing.] an idea, a fact or a situation from which sth is developed

data.chText: 他的论点在经济上有充分的根据。
data.enText: His arguments have a sound economic base.
a/the basis/foundation/base for/of sth
a secure/solid/sound/strong/weak basis/foundation/base
to form the basis/foundation/base of sth
to give sb/provide (sb with) a/the basis/foundation/base
to threaten/undermine the basis/foundations of sth
to be without basis/foundation

data.chText: 以上各词均指底部、最下部。
data.enText: These are all words for the lowest part of sth.
bottom
[usually sing.] the lowest part of sth
Footnotes are given at the bottom of each page.
I waited for them at the bottom of the hill.
base
[usually sing.] the lowest part of sth, especially the part or surface on which it rests or stands
The lamp has a heavy base.
foundation
[usually pl.] a layer of bricks, concrete, etc. that forms the solid underground base of a building
to lay the foundations of the new school
foot
[sing.] the lowest part of sth

data.chText: 她在楼梯底转过身来面对着他。
data.enText: At the foot of the stairs she turned to face him.

data.chText: foot用于有限的一些事物，最常与tree、hill/mountain、steps/stairs和page等连用。bottom适用的范围要广得多，其中也包括上面提到的与foot搭配的词。foot一般用于文学性较强的语境中。
data.enText: Foot is used to talk about a limited number of things: it is used most often with tree , hill/mountain , steps/stairs and page . Bottom can be used to talk about a much wider range of things, including those mentioned above for foot . Foot is generally used in more literary contexts.
bottom or foot?
at/near/towards the bottom/base/foot of sth
on the bottom/base of sth
(a) firm/solid/strong base/foundation(s)

simple_means.memory_skill: found 基础 + ation → 基础；地基

ex.chText: 良好的科研基础保障了去年经济目标的完成。
ex.enText: A good scientific research base ensures the achievement of last year's economic goals.

synonyms.bx: 指某事物的基底部分，一般用单数。也可以指知识、想法等的基础或军事组织的基地。

ex.enText: the basis of equality and mutual benefit

synonyms.bx: 指支持某事物并构成其发展基础的重要事实、观念、事、物等。

ex.chText: 工人们正在加固大桥的地基。
ex.enText: The workers are strengthening the foundation of the bridge.

ex.chText: 这条理论是有事实根据的。
ex.enText: This theory is built on a foundation of factual knowledge.

synonyms.bx: 指建筑物的地基，也可用来表示思想基础或基本原理。

data.enText: shake/rock the foundations of sth
shake/rock sth to its foundations
to cause people to question their basic beliefs about sth

data.chText: 这个问题从根本上动摇了法国的政治。
data.enText: This issue has shaken the foundations of French politics.

tr: the act of starting something for the first time
example: she looked forward to her initiation as an adult
the foundation of a new scientific society
it was built on a base of solid rock
he stood at the foot of the tower

tr: a woman's undergarment worn to give shape to the contours of the body
the fundamental assumptions from which something is begun or developed or calculated or explained
example: the whole argument rested on a basis of conjecture

tr: education or instruction in the fundamentals of a field of knowledge
example: he lacks the foundation necessary for advanced study

tr: an institution supported by an endowment
the basis on which something is grounded
example: there is little foundation for his objections

value.def: The foundation of something such as a belief or way of life is the things on which it is based.

example.ex: Best friends are the foundation of my life...
example.tran: 好朋友是我生命的支柱。

example.ex: The issue strikes at the very foundation of our community...
example.tran: 这个问题严重影响了我们社会的基本根基。

example.ex: This laid the foundations for later modern economic growth.
example.tran: 这为后来的现代经济发展奠定了基础。● If an event shakes the foundations of a society or a system of beliefs, it causes great uncertainty and makes people question their most deeply held beliefs. 动摇根基(或基础)

example.ex: The destruction of war and the death of millions of young people shook the foundations of Western idealism...
example.tran: 战争的破坏和数百万年轻人的死亡动摇了西方理想主义的根基。

example.ex: Emotional conflict may shake the foundations of even the strongest relationship.
example.tran: 情感冲突可以动摇哪怕是最牢固的人际关系的基础。

value.def: The foundations of a building or other structure are the layer of bricks or concrete below the ground that it is built on.
A foundation is an organization which provides money for a special purpose such as research or charity.
If a story, idea, or argument has no foundation, there are no facts to prove that it is true.

example.ex: Each complaint is analysed very closely, and if it has no foundation it is rejected.
example.tran: 每个投诉都经过仔细分析，如果发现没有依据就会予以驳回。

value.def: Foundation is a skin-coloured cream that you put on your face before putting on the rest of your make-up.

trans: 由某基金会维持的（机构），领取基金会提供的奖学金
理论依据；理论基石；理论基础；理论根基
坚实的基础（或地基）；坚实的基础
基石，奠基石(重要公共建筑奠基典礼时放置)
研究基金会；研究基金；研究基础；科研基金会；研究方法基础
美国国家科学基金会；国家科学基金会；国家科学基金；美国科学基金会；国家自然科学基金委员会
基础工程；地基工程；基礎工程；基础工程学；桥梁基础工程

partsOfSpeech.dec: found 基础 + ation 行为，过程，状态，结果 → 基础；地基
found 基础 + er 表名词 → 奠基者
funda〔= fund〕基础 + ment 表名词 → 基础
pro 前面 + found 基础 → 有基础在前面 → 深远的
pro 前面 + fund 基础 + ity 具备某种性质，状况 → 深刻；深度
un 无 + found 基础 + ed 表形容词 → 没有根基的 → 无事实根据的
